title: Quiz 2: The Pelvis & Perineum
description: Focused assessment on the bony pelvis, pelvic floor muscles, male and female reproductive viscera, and the perineal triangles.

questions.question: Which three bones fuse to form the acetabulum (hip socket)?
questions.explanation: The innominate bone (hip bone) is formed by the fusion of the Ilium, Ischium, and Pubis at the acetabulum.
questions.hint: These are the three components of the hip bone.

questions.question: Which of the following muscles constitute the Levator Ani? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Levator Ani consists of the Pubococcygeus (anterior), Puborectalis (intermediate), and Iliococcygeus (posterior). Coccygeus is part of the pelvic floor but NOT part of Levator Ani.
questions.hint: Think about the muscles that 'lift the anus'.

questions.question: Match the pelvic characteristic with the correct gender (Male vs Female):

richContent.content:
FeatureDescription
Pelvic InletShape varies significantly between sexes
Pubic ArchAngle width varies

questions.explanation: The female pelvis is adapted for childbirth: it is wider, shallower, has an oval inlet, and a wider pubic arch. The male pelvis is heavier with a heart-shaped inlet.
questions.hint: Which shape is better for the passage of a fetal head?

questions.question: The 'Water under the Bridge' relationship refers to the ureter passing posterior (under) to the uterine artery.
questions.explanation: TRUE. The ureter (water) passes UNDER the uterine artery (bridge) in the broad ligament. This is a critical landmark in hysterectomy to avoid ureteric injury.
questions.hint: Think of urine (water) flowing beneath the vessel.

questions.question: Arrange the parts of the male urethra from the bladder to the external meatus:
questions.explanation: Prostatic (through prostate) -> Membranous (through urogenital diaphragm) -> Spongy (Bulbous then Penile).
questions.hint: It starts at the prostate and ends at the penis.

questions.question: Which ligament provides the main support to the uterus, extending from the cervix to the lateral pelvic wall?
questions.explanation: The Cardinal (Transverse cervical) ligaments are the primary support for the uterus, effectively 'slinging' the cervix to the pelvic side walls.
questions.hint: It is also known as the transverse cervical ligament.

questions.question: The perineum is divided into two triangles by a line joining the ___BLANK___. The anterior triangle is the ___BLANK___ triangle.
questions.explanation: A line joining the ischial tuberosities divides the diamond-shaped perineum into the anterior Urogenital triangle and the posterior Anal triangle.
questions.hint: The bony points you sit on.

questions.question: Which of the following structures are contained within the Broad Ligament? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The broad ligament contains the tubes, ovarian ligament, round ligament, and uterine vessels. NOTE: The ureter passes *under* the broad ligament, not inside its layers.
questions.hint: Think of it as a drape covering the tubes and vessels.

questions.question: What is the name of the fibromuscular node located between the anal canal and the urogenital diaphragm, which serves as a crucial insertion point for pelvic floor muscles?
questions.explanation: The perineal body is the central anchor point of the perineum. Damage during childbirth can lead to pelvic floor weakness and prolapse.
questions.hint: It is the center point of the perineum.

questions.question: Read the clinical note below. Which artery is primarily responsible for the blood supply to the prostate?

richContent.content: Clinical Note: During prostatectomy, identifying the vascular pedicles is crucial to prevent hemorrhage. The arterial supply comes from a branch of the internal iliac artery that also supplies the bladder base.

questions.explanation: The inferior vesical artery (a branch of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac) supplies the prostate, seminal vesicles, and base of the bladder.
questions.hint: It supplies the lower (inferior) part of the bladder (vesica).

questions.question: Match the nerve with the pelvic structure it innervates:
questions.explanation: Pudendal = Somatic (voluntary). Pelvic Splanchnic = Parasympathetic (Empty bladder). Sympathetic = Fill bladder (relax detrusor, contract sphincter).
questions.hint: Parasympathetic = Peeing (S2-4).

questions.question: Where do the ejaculatory ducts open?
questions.explanation: The ejaculatory ducts open onto the Verumontanum (an elevation on the posterior wall of the prostatic urethra), on either side of the prostatic utricle.
questions.hint: It's a 'mountain' in the urethra.

questions.question: The lowest point of the peritoneal cavity in the female is the recto-uterine pouch (Pouch of Douglas).
questions.explanation: TRUE. The Pouch of Douglas lies between the rectum and the uterus/upper vagina. It is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in standing women.
questions.hint: Fluid collects here.

questions.question: Which of the following are contents of the Deep Perineal Pouch in the male? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Deep Pouch contains the membranous urethra, sphincter urethrae, and Cowper's glands. The Superficial Pouch contains the penile root and muscles (Ischiocavernosus, Bulbospongiosus).
questions.hint: The 'root' structures are superficial; the sphincter is deep.

questions.question: Arrange the layers of the scrotum from superficial to deep:
questions.explanation: Some Damn Englishman Called It The Testis: Skin, Dartos, External fascia, Cremaster, Internal fascia, Tunica vaginalis, Tunica albuginea.
questions.hint: Use the mnemonic 'Some Damn Englishman Called It The Testis'.

questions.question: Which artery is the main branch of the posterior trunk of the internal iliac artery?
questions.explanation: The Superior Gluteal artery is the largest branch of the posterior trunk. It exits via the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis.
questions.hint: It supplies the gluteal region superiorly.

questions.question: What structure separates the prostate gland from the rectum?
questions.explanation: The Fascia of Denonvilliers is a tough septum between the prostate/bladder anteriorly and the rectum posteriorly. It is an important barrier in cancer spread.
questions.hint: A fascial septum named after a French anatomist.

questions.question: The Pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels travel through a canal in the lateral wall of the ischiorectal fossa. What is the name of this canal?
questions.explanation: The pudendal canal (Alcock's canal) is formed by the fascia of the obturator internus muscle.
questions.hint: Starts with 'A'.

questions.question: Match the erectile tissue with the structure it forms:
questions.explanation: The penis has two corpora cavernosa (forming crura) and one corpus spongiosum (forming bulb and glans).
questions.hint: Spongiosum is central (urethra); Cavernosa are lateral.

questions.question: Which of the following ligaments resist rotation of the sacrum? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The sacrotuberous and sacrospinous ligaments bind the sacrum to the ischium, preventing the sacrum from tilting backward under body weight.
questions.hint: They connect the sacrum to the ischial tuberosity and spine.

questions.question: Lymphatic drainage from the lower vagina flows primarily to which lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Upper vagina -> Internal/External Iliac nodes. Lower vagina/Vulva -> Superficial Inguinal nodes.
questions.hint: The lower vagina behaves like the external skin/vulva.

questions.question: The internal anal sphincter is composed of voluntary skeletal muscle.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The INTERNAL sphincter is INVOLUNTARY smooth muscle (continuation of circular muscle). The EXTERNAL sphincter is VOLUNTARY skeletal muscle.
questions.hint: Internal = Involuntary.

questions.question: Trace the path of the Vas Deferens:
questions.explanation: The vas travels from the epididymis, through the spermatic cord/inguinal canal, down the pelvic wall, to the back of the bladder to join the seminal vesicle duct.
questions.hint: It goes from the scrotum 'up and over' to the prostate.

questions.question: Which muscle covers the crus of the penis?
questions.explanation: The Ischiocavernosus muscle covers the Corpus Cavernosum (Crus). The Bulbospongiosus covers the Bulb.
questions.hint: It covers the 'cavernosum' part.

questions.question: Regarding the position of the uterus, what does 'Anteverted' mean?

options.text: The uterus is bent forward on the cervix
The cervix is bent forward on the axis of the vagina

questions.explanation: Anteverted = Cervix axis bent forward on Vagina axis. Anteflexed = Uterus body bent forward on Cervix axis.
questions.hint: Version relates to the Vagina.
